1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. b4 Bxb4 5. c3 Ba5 6. d4 Bb6
1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. b4 Bxb4 5. c3 Ba5 6. d4 Bb6 7. dxe5 Nge7 8. O-O O-O 9. Ba3 h6
comment:
Necessary to prevent the Knight from coming to g5 and to be
able to play 10...Re8 which at present is not possible on account of 10.Bxf7+!
followed by 11.Ng5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. b4 Bxb4 5. c3 Ba5 6. d4 Bb6 7. dxe5 Nge7 8. O-O O-O 9. Ba3 h6 10. Nbd2 Re8 11. Nb3 Ng6 12. Bxf7+
comment:
A desperate decision,
but one which all the same hase some very good points to it.  12...

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. b4 Bxb4 5. c3 Ba5 6. d4 Bb6 7. dxe5 Nge7 8. O-O O-O 9. Ba3 h6 10. Nbd2 Re8 11. Nb3 Ng6 12. Bxf7+ Kxf7 13. Qd5+ Re6 14. Nfd4 Nf4
comment: ! Best,as Black had to stop the f-pawn from advancing.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. b4 Bxb4 5. c3 Ba5 6. d4 Bb6 7. dxe5 Nge7 8. O-O O-O 9. Ba3 h6 10. Nbd2 Re8 11. Nb3 Ng6 12. Bxf7+ Kxf7 13. Qd5+ Re6 14. Nfd4 Nf4 15. Nxe6 dxe6 16. Qxd8 Nxd8 17. Nd4 Nc6
comment:
! Better than 17...Bxd4 and 18...Ne2+ winning a pawn,
because here the important thing for Black is to develop his pieces and
endeavour to mantain the two Bishop.
